skill.name: biogeobears
skill.description: Set up and execute phylogenetic biogeographic analyses using BioGeoBEARS in R. Use when users request biogeographic reconstruction, ancestral range estimation, or want to analyze species distributions on phylogenies. Handles input file validation, data reformatting, RMarkdown workflow generation, and result visualization.
skill.summary: Set up and execute phylogenetic biogeographic analyses using BioGeoBEARS in R. Use when users reques...
skill.author: brunoasm

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate bioinformatics skill for phylogenetic biogeographic analysis. All 174 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES caused by the scanner misinterpreting documentation examples (R code showing package installation), scientific notation (d,e,j biogeographic parameters as 'weak crypto'), and relative file paths in examples as path traversal. No malicious intent detected.

content.value_statement: Phylogenetic biogeographic analysis helps researchers understand how species geographic ranges evolved over time. This skill automates the complete BioGeoBEARS workflow from input validation to publication-ready ancestral range visualizations.
actual_capabilities: Validates phylogenetic tree and geography input files for format compliance
Reformats CSV/TSV distribution data to BioGeoBEARS PHYLIP format
Generates parameterized RMarkdown analysis scripts for six biogeographic models
Compares DEC, DIVALIKE, BAYAREALIKE models with/without founder-event (+J) parameter
Creates publication-ready ancestral range visualizations on phylogenies
Produces HTML reports with statistical results and model comparison tables
limitations: Requires BioGeoBEARS R package and dependencies (ape, rmarkdown, knitr)
Analysis runtime scales exponentially with number of geographic areas
Generates analysis scripts but cannot execute the actual R analysis itself

use_cases.title: Ancestral range reconstruction
use_cases.description: Reconstruct where ancestors of species lived on their phylogenetic tree using DEC, DIVALIKE, and BAYAREALIKE models.

use_cases.title: Dispersal and extinction analysis
use_cases.description: Estimate rates of geographic range expansion, contraction, and founder-event speciation across a clade.

use_cases.title: Historical biogeography
use_cases.description: Understand historical biogeographic patterns to inform conservation prioritization and predict responses to climate change.

prompt_templates.title: Basic analysis request
prompt_templates.scenario: User has tree and distribution data
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a Newick phylogeny of [NUMBER] species and their geographic distributions across [NUMBER] areas. Run a BioGeoBEARS analysis to reconstruct ancestral ranges.

prompt_templates.title: Model comparison
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to compare specific models
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare DEC, DEC+J, DIVALIKE, and DIVALIKE+J models on my phylogeny. Which model has the best AIC weight? Explain the biological meaning of the parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Data reformatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert my species distribution CSV file to BioGeoBEARS format and validate it against my phylogenetic tree file.

prompt_templates.title: Visualization focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate an RMarkdown script that produces pie chart visualizations of ancestral ranges on my phylogeny for all six BioGeoBEARS models.

output_examples.input: Run BioGeoBEARS analysis on my 30-species bird phylogeny with their island distributions
output: Validated 30 species across 5 islands (A, B, C, D, E)
Generated RMarkdown script with 6 model comparison
Models: DEC, DEC+J, DIVALIKE, DIVALIKE+J, BAYAREALIKE, BAYAREALIKE+J
To run: cd biogeobears_analysis && bash run_analysis.sh
Expected runtime: 30-60 minutes for full model comparison

output_examples.input: Convert my species distribution CSV to BioGeoBEARS format
output: Converted presence/absence data to PHYLIP format
Validated species names match tree tip labels
File is valid for BioGeoBEARS analysis

output_examples.input: Which BioGeoBEARS model is best for my island dataset?
output: The +J parameter significantly improves fit (LRT p < 0.001)
Suggesting founder-event speciation is important for island biogeography

best_practices: Always validate input files before running full analysis to catch species name mismatches early
Use all six models for comprehensive model comparison rather than testing only one
Set max_range_size conservatively (number of areas minus one) to avoid computational explosion
anti_patterns: Running analysis without validating that species names match between tree and geography files
Using very high max_range_size values (greater than 5) without understanding computational implications
Reporting results from only one model without AIC-based model comparison

faq.question: What does the +J parameter mean?
faq.answer: The +J adds founder-event speciation, allowing new species to disperse to distant areas during speciation events.

faq.question: How many geographic areas can I include?
faq.answer: More than 5-6 areas dramatically increases computation time. Consider combining adjacent areas if possible.

faq.question: Which model should I use?
faq.answer: Run all six models and compare using AIC weights. The best-supported model indicates which processes best explain your data.

faq.question: What if species names do not match?
faq.answer: Use the validate_geography_file.py script to identify mismatches, then edit either the tree or geography file to align names.

faq.question: Can I use an unrooted tree?
faq.answer: BioGeoBEARS requires rooted trees. Root your tree using an outgroup species and provide the rooted version.

faq.question: How long will the analysis take?
faq.answer: Small datasets (less than 50 species, 5 or fewer areas): 10-30 minutes. Large datasets (more than 100 species): 1-6 hours.
